headline.main: What We Know: Pentagon Pushing More Family-Friendly Military
headline.print_headline: What We Know: Pentagon Pushing More Family-Friendly Military

docs.lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization (WHO) said on Thursday the Zika virus, linked to severe birth defects in thousands of babies in Brazil, is "spreading explosively" and may infect 3 to 4 million people in the Americas, including 1.5 million in Brazil.

headline.main: Factbox: Facts About the Zika Virus and the Current Outbreak
headline.print_headline: Factbox: Facts About the Zika Virus and the Current Outbreak

docs.snippet: The World Health Organization (WHO) said on Thursday the Zika virus, linked to severe birth defects in thousands of babies in Brazil, is "spreading explosively" and may infect 3 to 4 million people in the Americas, including 1.5 million in Brazil.

docs.lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Ash Carter on Thursday unveiled a series of family-friendly proposals for the military that would increase parental leave, child care and health care coverage to bolster efforts to recruit and retain high-quality service members.

headline.main: Pentagon Chief Seeks to Improved Family Leave, Child Care
headline.print_headline: Pentagon Chief Seeks to Improved Family Leave, Child Care

docs.snippet: Defense Secretary Ash Carter on Thursday unveiled a series of family-friendly proposals for the military that would increase parental leave, child care and health care coverage to bolster efforts to recruit and retain high-quality service members.

docs.lead_paragraph: Maria Erlinda Guzman desperately wants a baby, and has been undergoing fertility treatments at El Salvador's largest women's hospital. But now, she fears her dream of motherhood may be dashed by Zika.

headline.main: In Face of Zika Virus, Women Ponder Abortion, Childlessness
headline.print_headline: In Face of Zika Virus, Women Ponder Abortion, Childlessness

docs.snippet: Maria Erlinda Guzman desperately wants a baby, and has been undergoing fertility treatments at El Salvador's largest women's hospital. But now, she fears her dream of motherhood may be dashed by Zika.

docs.lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization must coordinate a broad international response to the spread of the virus.

headline.main: Zika Virus Requires an Urgent Response
headline.print_headline: Another Virus Requiring an Urgent Response

docs.abstract: Editorial urges World Health Organization to swiftly address emerging threat of Zika virus in South and Central America; claims series of actions taken so far by range of countries and institutions will not do enough to prevent potential spread of virus; calls for convening of emergency committee to brief WHO officials on most effective strategies.
docs.snippet: The World Health Organization must coordinate a broad international response to the spread of the virus.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Health authorities said reported cases of microcephaly — a condition in which newborns have abnormally small heads — had climbed to 4,180 since October. Brazil typically has 150 cases annually.

headline.main: Reports of Zika-Linked Birth Defect Rise in Brazil
headline.print_headline: Reports of Zika-Linked Birth Defect Rise in Brazil

docs.abstract: Brazilian health officials announce Zika virus is typically not life-threatening, but warns country's outdated testing methods cannot prove or disprove virus's link to surge in cases of microcephaly; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which has advised pregnant women to avoid traveling to affected regions, says evidence suggests connection and recommends further research.
docs.snippet: Health authorities said reported cases of microcephaly — a condition in which newborns have abnormally small heads — had climbed to 4,180 since October. Brazil typically has 150 cases annually.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Advocacy groups call for supporting women’s reproductive rights in light of the government advisory.

headline.main: The Zika Virus Leaves Salvadoran Women in a Serious Bind
headline.print_headline: The Zika Virus Leaves Salvadoran Women in a Bind

docs.snippet: Advocacy groups call for supporting women’s reproductive rights in light of the government advisory.

docs.lead_paragraph: Invisible Sentinel says its food testing technology offers a faster, easier and cheaper way to test for pathogens and spoilage in foods.

headline.main: Food Testing Start-Up Looks to Stand Out With a New Wrinkle
headline.print_headline: A Food Testing Start-Up Looks to Stand Out in a Highly Competitive Field

docs.abstract: Philiadelphia-based company Invisible Sentinel has developed patented food testing technology, called Veriflow, that detects contamination more quickly, cheaply and easily than available technologies.
docs.snippet: Invisible Sentinel says its food testing technology offers a faster, easier and cheaper way to test for pathogens and spoilage in foods.

docs.lead_paragraph: Raonic beat Gaël Monfils on Wednesday to advance to play Andy Murray on Friday. Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer are matched in the other semifinal.

headline.main: Milos Raonic Crashes the Australian Open Semifinals Party
headline.print_headline: Raonic, Amateur Art Critic, Crafts Bid to Crash the Big 4

docs.abstract: Christopher Clarey On Tennis column holds that Milos Raonic has surprised many this season, making it to semifinals of Australian Open tennis tournament, along with Novak Djokovic, Roger Federer and Andy Murray--three members of Big 4.
docs.snippet: Raonic beat Gaël Monfils on Wednesday to advance to play Andy Murray on Friday. Novak Djokovic and Roger Federer are matched in the other semifinal.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama on Tuesday called for the rapid development of tests, vaccines and treatments to fight the mosquito-transmitted Zika virus, which has been linked to birth defects and could spread to the United States in warmer months.

headline.main: Obama Calls for Rapid Zika Research as Virus Seen Spreading
headline.print_headline: Obama Calls for Rapid Zika Research as Virus Seen Spreading

docs.snippet: President Barack Obama on Tuesday called for the rapid development of tests, vaccines and treatments to fight the mosquito-transmitted Zika virus, which has been linked to birth defects and could spread to the United States in warmer months.
